bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 17, 1940

div1.p: Kean responds in detail to Hench's letter concerning the yellow fever experiments. He sends his diary from late 1900 and a copy of a speech at the dedication of Walter Reed's birthplace.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 17, 1940

My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
This is going to be a long letter, and one
too long postponed so I will write it on letter, in-
stead of note, paper- I have been too much upset to
write it sooner as I buried two weeks ago today
my youngest brother - a splendid fellow whom I
loved as a son- He was twenty years younger than
I am- Your good letter of Sept. 12 is before me
for reply and I have numbered the paragraphs
for convenience of reference - 5 A G E on p. 1 and 6 & 7 F. B
& 8 on p. 2 the latter being the P. S.

A The Cuban y. f. episode is as you say dear to me
and you need not worry about me- I appreciate
very keenly the value of your work and that you
have got Gen. Truby and me to work together on
it and supply materials for a revaluation of
the contributions of the actors-

(There is too much headline to this paper I will look up some
plain sheets- tho they may not match it)

B. I hope you have received Truby's sketch by this time-
He wanted me to read it before sending it to you
so as to iron out any differences in our recollect-
ion of details- His contributions are far more
detailed than mine and far more valuable- His
work at the hospital of which he was part of the time
in commenced & when not, was executive officer,
brought him into intimate contact with the work
of the commission, which I did not have- My
office was busy with the troubles of the medical
service all over western Cuba & the 1001 sani-
tary questions of the posts and camps; and the
16 Cuban orphan asylums that old Clara
Barton established inside of a month & then
went off & left them on my hands without
any records of rents or agreements or even a
list of employe's and inmates, or any visible
means of support - but that is another story-
Therefore I did not know what part Agramonte
took in the mosquito work of the Commission after
Lazear's death and am quite willing to accept
Truby's statement of it- But I do not think it of
enough importance to challenge A's veracity
about after forty years- Gen. Truby in a former
letter found fault with me for publishing in Chap. 4
Par. 2.
3
p. 25 & 26 (Senate Doc. No. 520. 61st Congress 2. Session) of the
Senate Doc. 822 Yellow Fever, which you have, Agra-
monte's statement of his share of the work of the board.
I put it in because A. had come to me and com-
plained that I had done him great injustice in a
former Senate doc. (No. 10 59thCongress) page 21 of Yellow Fever-
This I had written on Carroll's authority, having no
suspicion of the hostility that C. had for A. So I
thought it only fair to let A. make his own state-
ment on the subject- In Truby's nice, gentle way
he included Ireland in this statement of Agram-
onte's share, but, as Gen. Ireland said, he had no-
first hand knowledge of the matter and had
nothing to do with the publication of the document-
The Surgeon Gen. OReilly signed it, but as I recall, his
apporval & signature was all that he contributed-
I had many contacts with Agramonte when I was
in charge of the sanitary dept. of Cuba in the Second
Intervention (1906 to 1909) and my opinion of Agra-
monte is better than Truby's, as his opinion of
Carroll is better than mine-

par. C. I have no cloak of modesty about what help I was
able to give Reed- As all the medical personel
of the Provinces of Havana & Pinar del Rio was
under my supervision I could give him support
in having many little things done, but nothing
to speak of- After he was established at Colum-
bia barracks, Truby could do much more for him
4
par C cont.) than I could- My only serious contribution
to his success was in persuading him to ask
Gen. Wood for money to establish Camp Lazear &
hire Spanish immigrants for the experiments-
When I proposed this to Reed on our drive to
Havana he made no reply, but seemed wrapped in
deep thought, and until he made his request to Gen.
Wood I did not know whether he would do it-
It may be that he had it in mind to do it any
way, but if so he did not tell any one
I described this at length in an address as Belroi which I
will send you with my diary, Vol. IV. I will also
send, if I can put my hand on it, a copy of the Editorial
Review of the Life of Gorgas which I wrote at the
request of the Surgeon General (Ireland) and of Mrs
Walter Reed- I put this in, as Gen Truby speaks
of it in his letter to you of Sept. 10, of which he
sent me a copy- Truby is right that Gorgas was
the last man in the world who would try to filch
any of Reed's laurels-

par. D I hope to be able to get down to Moran's dinner
at the Univ. of Va. on Oct. 25 - but I am so weak on
my legs and with such an unreliable old pump (fibril-
lation) that I can never be sure of my self- I do not
think I can venture to get out to your celebration at
Washington Pa. I had a nice letter from the President
5
par. D cont.) of the Washington & Jefferson College a few
days ago- I hope to meet your brother and his
wife at the Univ. Va- I had suspected that you
had a hand in the Moran dinner-

Par. E- I will get off the diary by express or reg. mail
today or tomorrow with the reprints- I have looked
about for a photograph of myself during the
days of the Episode but cannot find one-
The nearest approach to it is a photo. of the
portrait that the Cuban Nat. Board of Health had
painted of me in 1909- Mrs Kean has this
framed but says that I can take it out to
send to you if you will return it with the
diary- I am somewhat ashamed to send such
a casual & personal lot of joltings as my diary
contains, with so little account of the great affairs
which went on under my eyes and in which
I was intensely interested- But it is a factual,
not a discriptive, record and made in haste; and
the busier I was the less I wrote- I see that during
my terrible struggle to create & run a hospital in
the typhoid epidemic in Camp Cuba Libes at Jackson-
ville, Fla. I did not make a note between Aug. 26 and
Sept. 19th 1898- That period is still a nightmare to me
but I won out and the inspection on Sept. 25 put me
on the map with the Surgeon General (Sternberg) and was
a turning point in my career (p. 82)
6-
Par. E cont.) There was no panic in the army- The Chief
Surgeon Col. later Surg. General OReilly thought
that all the women, even the trained nurses, should
be sent home, but the women or many of them chose
to stay and take their chances with their husbands
The nurses too were willing to stay, altho. I told
those at Columbia Bks. that they would be sent to
care for army personnel who were sick with
y. f. even in Marianao- The soldiers knew that
if the disease invaded the barracks they would
be made safe by quarantines and ordering them into a camp (tents)
at a distance from the Barracks- They were forbid-
den to leave the military reservation- Of course
the Cuban civil population considered themselves
immune and so had no fear of y. f.

Par F. I have no objection at this late date to your making
reference to my last visit to Major Edwards-

Par G The photo of the Lazear Memorial has not arrived- Doubtless
it will come later- I will be glad to see it- As stated above
I do not feel able to go to the dedication, much as I would
like to do so-

Par. H Dr. C. E. Finlay came to see me and told me about
his book- I told him of the dinner to his father and Reed
mentioned in my Belroi address- He seemed interested
but made us comment- I know Dr Edward Angle's who
was my neighbor on Gen. Lee St. in Quemados de Marianao-
7.
H contd) Has Angle's heterodox opinions on the location
of Camp Lazear also? I do not recall that he had
anything to do with the Episode-
Remarks on your Memorandum

Par 2. Truby says that Lazear was on duty in charge of
the laboratory at Camp Columbia Hospital where
detailed on the Reed Y. F. Board- This agrees with
my recollection-

Par. 6- The 7th Army Corps went to Havana in Dec. 1898
in many detachments and went into camps which
they pitched west of the Almendares River which is
west of Havana- Most of the units were camped
as I recollect about Buena Vista Station on the narrow gage
R. R. between Havana & Marianao- The last of the
7th Army Corps Vol. regiments left Cuba on April 19th
1899- The 7 U. S. Can replaced them and camped
where the Ciudad Militar now is and there were
several batteries of light Artillery which were brought
out from Havana to Camp Columbia in the spring
Gen. Lee's Hdqrs moved from tents into the Toledo
Casa on the Calzada Real on May 13th 1899-
The wooden barracks were built in May & June 1899
but Gen. Lee on my advice would not allow the
command to occupy them until satisfactory sanitary
8
Par. 6 contd) arrangements for disposal of extra were made by the Q. M. Dept-
who had put in utterly bad arrangements, against the
advice of the Medical Dept- They were occupied about
July 21st 1899- The Hospital was built much earlier-
These wooden buildings were still in use during the
2nd Intervention and when I left there in Feb. 1909-
The Cuban Gov. replaced them- I dont know when-

Par. 8. Godfrey was the Senior Medical officer at Pinar
del Rio- I think he was a Captain in the regular
Army & he may have the Volunteer rank of major
as I had until 1901- Cooke was an acting Asst
Surgeon with the relative rank of 1st Lieut- Major
P. E. Lee Michie was a major & the Adjt. Gen of the
Dept- a fine, handsome, capable officer & a relation
of your sister-in-law doubtless, as he was from
Albemarle Co. Va. He died in France in the World
War at Ronen with rank of Brig. Gen- At Mar-
ianao he was practically the chief of staff and
drew up all the orders-

Par. 10 I do not know- I was absent from Cuba
on sick leave from July 3 to Aug. 13- 1899 1900-

Par 11. It was not the Chairman of the famous typhoid fever
Board who died, but Dr Edw. O. Shakespeare of Phila
the Recorder of the Board,
a very important member- Major Walter Reed was the
Chairman of the Board and Victor C. Vaughan of Aun Arbor
9
who was the third- I have just been reading over
the account of its work in Vaughan's delightful auto-
biography “A Doctor's Memories”- Vaughan completed
the Report after Reed's death-

Par. 19. Reed's purpose in visiting Gen. Wood on Oct. 12th as
stated by him to me was to get Gen. Wood's per-
mission to go to the U. S. to consult the Surgeon
General- It was the latter whose approval for
experiments on human beings he felt to be prima-
rily necessary- If he had the intention of con-
sulting Gen. Wood on this point he did not say
so to me - even after my talk with him on the
way to Havana on Oct. 12 - about asking Gen Wood's
help- No officer under Gen. Wood's command
could leave Cuba without authority from him or from
Washin the War Dept-

Par. 22. On Page 104 of the Senate doc. Yellow Fever you
will find listed 10 Privates of the Hospital Corps- Kissinger
and the cases VIII Jernigan to XVI Sonntag- Evidently these
are the 9 referred to in the first par on page 71 of the Doc.
and one additional who came to the Camp later-
Moran is not one of the H. C. privates as he was there an
H. C. clerk- The immune one was I suppose Weather-
walks who after the fomites test Dec. 21 to Jan 10 - was
bitten by 12 mosquitos who had fed on case VII 22 days before-
(see bottom of p. 102 Y. F.)
Gen. Truby can tell you more about these men than
I can- I do not recall that Reed told me about
the circumstances of the volunteering of Moran and
Kissenger- I would rely on Moran rather than Kissinger
10
Par 22 contd) I find a notation that Weatherwalks
refused to be bitten by two mosquitoes that had
been infected from Kissinger 65 days before. This
was on Feb 14, 1901 that he refused-

Truby can tell you how the H. C. volunteers were
approached-
Par- 23 I do not know, ask Truby or Moran-
" 27 I do not know

" 29 I drove out there and saw it once I think
I do not know what was done with the
buildings.

Par. 49 I am entirely in accordance with your
statements in this paragraph- I remember
Dr. Juan Guiteras saying to me that Dr Finlay
had excellent epidemiological arguments
in favor of this theory but I do not recollect
that he claimed that he had made successful
experimental proof of it- My account of the dinner
given by the doctors of Havana Dec. 22nd, 1900 to celebrate
Reed's demonstration of Finlays theory shows that
attitude of Guiteras at the time- It is in a letter
I wrote to Mr Clemons of Sept. 22, 1939 and asked
him to furnish you a photographic copy- I hope he
did so- There is an account of it also in my Belroi address inclosed

I have been awkward enough to cut my right fore-
finger with a sharp knife and so Mrs. Kean has been
11
good enough to be my amannensis and finish this
Memorandum which I am most anxious to get off
to you. I do not know the date of your address
at Washington and Jefferson College, but imagine that
you have not any too much time.

Par. 95 I am glad that you met Dr. Albertini, if he is
the same one who was on the Yellow Fever
Diagnosis Board with Dr. Carlos Finlay and
General Gorgas, he is a very agreeable and capable
man. By the way I notice that your stenographer
spells the name of the flamboyant tree incorrectly
in several places where it occurs. She spells the
first syllable “fram” in each place, the name refers
to the gorgeous red and yellow flowers that it bears
in the spring.

Par. 100 It is certainly true that Carroll didn't take
his experiment with the loaded mosquitoes
seriously. This is the only possible excuse for
12
his having vitiated the value of the experiment by going
into Havana which was out of bounds, and of all
places going to Agramonte's post mortem room. As re-
gards the infection of Lazear, Reed told me the story of
Lazear's having been bitten by a wild mosquito at Las Animas
Hospital. If he had his doubts as to the truth of this
story he did not express them to me. It was evidently
the story he wanted generally accepted. I never heard
any doubt of it expressed until within the last few
years by general Truby. I never heard at what
date the biting at Las Animas occurred and so the
question of incubation period was not raised in my
mind. The circumstances of the infection of X Y
were not known to me. Agramonte's account of it
I never heard from him or anyone else until he
published it. I have never entirely accepted it, but
I have no other facts to put against it. The story
which Kissinger is said to have told that Lazear
put a loaded mosquito on X Y in his sleep I do not
believe a word of. Such an act would be totally
13
inconsistent with Lazear's noble character.

Par.
101-104 As to Mrs. Rodriguez-Leon's report of her father's
(Dr. Agramonte's) report of the agreement between
Lazear and himself I don't know what to think.
It is all quite new to me, and I have my
doubts. I shall be curious to learn what
general Truby thinks of it.

Par. 109 104 Quemados was the N. E. end of Mariano.
It was simply a quarter of the town, as Georgetown
is a district of Washington, Quemados means
“burned,” and it was at some remote period a
burned district

Par.
111 & 112 I cannot with any certainty locate the cases
of yellow fever in Mariano which Reed in-
dicates by the street numbers, The bare be
except 102 Real which is the only one given
in the bare list of yellow fever cases which I
find in my diary pp 169-170. At that number lived
Private Ballentine, Company D, Eighth Infantry
14
taken sick May 26, 1900. Private TEETER,
Hosp. Corps, (my orderly), June 1st, and
(Private?) HambuRGER, June 10th.

No. 20 General Lee Street may have been where
Captain Hepburn lived. He was taken sick June 20th
the day before I was. You will find a note of
his case on page 172 of my diary. I was myself
sick when I wrote that note. In the map
that you sent me photo 5 portion of Cuban Army
map 1937 you locate General Lee's Headquarters
on Calsada Real at the head of General Lee
Street. I think the handsome building which you
visited with Moran and which was identified by
Moran as the Headquarters is not located there
but opposite the little park three blocks further
down the Calsada, just beyond the black
marked 86 on that map. I have sat too
often on the portico and listened to the band
play in this little park to be mistaken about
that. Also every day for a year 5 or 6 months
15
I used to walk from my house No. 27 General Lee
st. up the street to the Calsada and then along the
Calsada to the Headquarters building. Dr. Angle's
lived on the same block on General Lee St. with me.

Par. 114 Yellow Fever Ward. This was as you know
across the railroad from Camp Columbia and as I
recollect it further north towards La Plaza than
you have it located in red pencil on the Cuban Army
Map. It was composed as I recollect it partly of
framed tents and partly of huts of the same size
as of a hospital tent. My recollection is that Hepburn
and I occupied a hut, being in the same room.
General Truby's recollection about this would however
settle the matter. The Camp Model of Columbia
Barracks, Quemados 1900-1901 by Y. PeREz now
at Carlisle I recollect having examined where
it was at the Army Medical Museum. My im-
pression is that it gives a quite accurate idea
of the buildings but is not entirely accurate
as to relative distances and locations as he
16
had to get all of his buildings on a relatively small
area. PeRez is certainly correct about the bridge
over the railroad.
Par 118 & 119 These are covered by the above.

Par 122 I do not know that Dr. R. P. CooKE has
ever written anything about his experiences. I never
heard that he refused to submit to the bites of mos-
quitos. He is now living in Lexington, Va. His name is
on the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor, published in the
back of each Army Register. Have you a copy
of this Roll? If not you can doubtless get one
by application to the Adjutant General, U. S. Army.

Par 123 As stated above Major Michie died at
Ronen, about June 1918, being then a Brigadier
General, National Army. (An able and lovable man)

Par 125 & 126 At the time of Reed's death he was
librarian of the great Army Medical Library
then known as “Library of the Surgeon General's office”
He probably therefore had two desks one for the
Library and another as in connection with his
17
his work as an instructor in the Army Medical School.
I imagine both were examined for papers connected with
the Yellow Fever work. There was however I think no
formal investigation. It was probably assumed that they
would turn up in the course of time, and certainly the
matter did not appear to have then the importance which
it has now.

Dr. Roger Post Ames died a number of years ago
while living somewhere in Central America in the Em-
ployment of the Public Health Service. He has a wife who is
very much alive and who has for some years been
making efforts through Senator Shepherd of Texas
to have Ames' name placed on the Yellow Fever Roll
of Honor. The Surgeon General has put on record his
opinion that Ames did not contribute anything to
the conclusions of the Reed Yellow Fever Commission
and his name should not be on that Roll-
Although like many others he did good service in
the care of the yellow fever sick. In this opinion
I entirely concuR, although he took good care of
me in my illness.

I hope that this long memorandum may arrive
in time to assist you in the preparation of your
18
address. You can send it to General Truby
if you wish to have his opinion on it or any
part of it.

closer.seg:
P. S. I think it would be tactful and just for as
in all our writing to allude to the mosquito theory
as the Findlay theory (just as the Cubans do) which
was proved by the Reed commission- So we
should applaud the marking by them, with a
monument, of the place where Lazear died, but
should get the inscription changed to show
that fact- Then the site of Camp Lazear,
which you have correctly located, should be
fittingly marked to show that it is the site of
Camp Lazear where the Reed Commission
demonstrated the truth of the Finlay theory of
the transmission of yellow fever by the mosquito
Aedes Egypti- Sept. 20 I will now pack up this
M S S & the diary and send them by Express.
Please return the letter as soon as you conveniently
can- Mrs Kean is much disturbed at my letting
it go out of the house-
J. R. K.
